providers.name: David Oh
providers.designation: Chief medical officer at Hoxworth Blood Center
providers.story: Blood is considered to be a drug and we're regulated by the FDA. My job is to make sure that the blood that we collect, process and distribute is safe for the donors and for the recipients. I think of blood donation as a donor giving freely of their life essence and creating a link with someone in need, which is inspiring!

providers.name: John Bush
providers.story: Working in the hospital as a patient transporter gave me a chance to see lots of careers. I knew I wanted to be hands-on with patients. So, I went to Cincinnati State, got my Associate’s degree and passed my medical boards in respiratory therapy. That opened new opportunities for me at the hospital and eventually got me to the sidelines at Cincinnati Bengals games, where I’m part of the emergency action plan to support players. On my best days, I get to help people breathe better and get back to their families.

providers.name: Lori Crosby
providers.story: We see patients as holistic — with their minds and bodies connected. Behaviors, such as exercise, or how we eat, or when we take medication, might help address a range of concerns. My work focuses on those behaviors. How do we optimize and make it easy for people to do what they need to do to care for their conditions and themselves?

providers.name: Lori Pierson
providers.designation: Hoxworth Blood Center donor care technician
providers.story: I assist with collecting blood products to provide hospitals and surgery centers with the supply they need to help individuals who need blood transfusions. I get to know some of the regular donors and learn about their families — I look forward to asking them about how they are doing and to thanking them for giving. These volunteers help the community and save lives, and I love playing a role in that.

providers.name: Margaret Chamberlain
providers.story: We are skeleton photographers. Doctors can't see what's going on inside someone’s body, and imaging is the next best thing. My job involves a lot of thinking outside of the box. I may not be able to take an x-ray in a textbook way, because it would make the patient uncomfortable, but I always find a way to get the doctors the information they need without harming the patient or making them feel worse.

providers.name: Molly Thomas
providers.story: I help young people work with their muscles to move their bodies as well as they can. That looks different for everybody. Without your muscles working together, you would not be able to do things like sit and stand, run and jump. Your muscles are the dynamic part of you. They help you be a person. They’re what makes you fun!

providers.name: Robert Bohinski, M.D., Ph.D.
providers.story: There are mechanical aspects of the spine that keep us upright and moving, and there are the parts that interact with our nervous system that keep us out of pain and send healthy signals to our arms and legs. That blend of bones and nerves hooked me as a medical student. I aim to keep people as active as they can be — if you've got a bad spine, it's hard to do anything well.

providers.name: Misty Vaccariello, LMT
providers.story: Licensed massage therapy is the perfect missing piece in an athlete’s life between orthopedics and physical therapy. I’ve been fortunate to work with hobbyists and professional athletes and return their comfort and mobility without medications. Having the ability to relieve an injured client’s pain and help them get back to their ideal fitness level makes me want to help as many people as I can.
